TEXT: The applicant is a NORP national , born in DATE and currently serving a prison sentence in the GPE . He is represented before the ORG by PERSON , a lawyer practising in GPE .

On DATE , upon request of the public prosecutor , the investigating judge ( rechter - commissaris ) of ORG ( Arrondissementsrechtbank ) of GPE opened a preliminary judicial investigation ( gerechtelijk vooronderzoek ) against Mr X. , a NORP national residing in the GPE and who was suspected of being involved in importation of cocaine . At some later point in time , a preliminary judicial investigation was also opened against PERSON , the spouse of Mr X. After Mr X. and PERSON had become aware of these investigations , they left the GPE for GPE ( GPE ) . Although , following their departure from the GPE , the criminal investigations against them were not actively pursued , they were not formally closed .

In DATE , ORG ( ORG ) opened an investigation under the code name “ Tropical Wizzard ” against a number of persons suspected of cocaine trafficking and money laundering activities . CARDINAL of these suspects was Mr X. As it appeared from tapped telephone conversations of Mr X. , that he was involved in the transport of drugs to the GPE , the responsible Assistant Attorney for LOC of GPE , Ms NORP , requested GPE for LOC of GPE on DATE for an order allowing the disclosure of intercepted wire conversations to the GPE criminal investigation authorities . After having obtained this judicial disclosure order on DATE , the GPE criminal investigation authorities were provided with the intercepted communications .

On DATE , on the basis of the DATE LAW between the GPE and the GPE with regard to mutual assistance in criminal matters , the public prosecutor PERSON addressed a letter rogatory to the GPE authorities to the effect of making available the results of the criminal investigation in the GPE , including the tapped telephone conversations , in order to explore the possibilities of a joint investigation of the activities of Mr X. in particular .

From the information made available by the GPE authorities , it appeared that around DATE , a ship carrying a large quantity of cocaine destined for the GPE had left a NORP harbour and that Mr X. had contacts by telephone with persons in the GPE . CARDINAL of the telephone numbers concerned was CARDINAL - CARDINAL*****. This number was registered in the GPE under the name of a person called PERSON and used by a person referred to as “ LOC ” .

On DATE , the preliminary judicial investigation against Mr X. in the GPE was reactivated and permission was obtained from the investigating judge to tap a number of telephone lines including the number CARDINAL - CARDINAL*****. In addition , a preliminary judicial investigation was opened against Mr PERSON , who would represent Mr X. in the GPE .

It appeared from telephone conversations tapped and a large number of observations that the ship from GPE would arrive in the harbour of LOC ( GPE ) , where the drugs would be collected by a number of NORP with the aid of divers and subsequently be brought by car to the GPE . Observations allowed the police to identify CARDINAL cars in which the drugs would be transported . CARDINAL of the cars , a ORG Clio , guided the other CARDINAL cars to the final place of delivery . Mr X. was found to be in contact with the driver of the ORG Clio via the mobile telephone line CARDINAL - CARDINAL*****. In TIME CARDINAL DATE , a large number of persons involved were arrested and taken into detention . A total of QUANTITY . of cocaine was seized . Mr X. and the applicant were amongst the arrested persons . The applicant was arrested sitting in the ORG Clio , shortly after this car had arrived at the place where the cocaine was planned to be delivered .
Following the closure of the preliminary judicial investigation , the applicant was charged with narcotics offences and summoned to appear before ORG of GPE in order to stand trial .

In its judgment of DATE , following adversarial proceedings , ORG convicted the applicant of being involved in narcotics offences and of membership of a criminal organisation . He was sentenced to DATE imprisonment . The applicant filed an appeal with ORG ( Gerechtshof ) of GPE .

In the course of the hearing held on DATE before ORG , the defence requested the court , inter alia , to hear a number of witnesses , including PERSON , the GPE Assistant Attorney having dealt with the investigation conducted in the GPE , in relation to her request of DATE and the role played by a certain PERSON in the investigation in the GPE . The defence did not find it necessary to take direct evidence from Mr S.
On DATE , after having deliberated , ORG rejected the request to take evidence from PERSON and a number of other witnesses . It considered on these points :
< Translation >
“ As a general framework for the decisions to be taken , the court considers the following at the outset .

CARDINAL . The case has its origins in a broad investigation of international cocaine trafficking conducted in the GPE under the name Tropical Wizzard . The criminal investigation in the GPE has been set into motion after having obtained on CARDINAL DATE disclosure of NORP tapping data , in accordance with the provisions of LAW between the Kingdom of the GPE and GPE on mutual assistance in criminal matters … . The tapping data have thus formed the basis of the start of the investigation in the GPE . With the aid of further taps and observations in the GPE , the investigation has been pursued , which led on DATE to the finding of QUANTITY . cocaine and the apprehension of a large number of suspects , amongst whom the accused .

CARDINAL . The accused now request the court , in brief , to assess inter alia the course of events in relation to the lawfulness of the use in the GPE of NORP investigation results . The question is whether it is incumbent on the GPE judge to do so . The court considers that in principle this is not the case . The existence of a treaty on mutual assistance in criminal matters is based on the principle that it may be relied upon that the Government , to whom a request is addressed and in application of that treaty , will exercise its powers in conformity with the treaty norms , which may be considered as being in conformity with the essential norms of public order valid in the GPE . Only where there is a concrete reason to assume that in the application of such powers those norms would have been disrespected , a reason would arise to examine the lawfulness indicated . The court considers that those norms include those of the international human rights treaties .

CARDINAL . For the question when acts are contrary to the NORP public order it is possible , in connection with the instant case and noting the contents of the defence argument , to consider the case - law relating to the ( in)admissibility of the public prosecution department in its prosecution . This appears , inter alia , from the so - called PERSON judgment … , namely that the far reaching sanction of inadmissibility of the prosecution can only follow in case of serious breaches of the principles of proper proceedings ( behoorlijke procesorde ) by which , deliberately or with gross negligence , the suspect ’s interests in his right to a fair hearing have been disrespected .

CARDINAL . In relation to the defence ’s requests seeking an investigation into the lawfulness of the GPE criminal investigation , the court considers at the outset that a possible flaw of the lawfulness , insofar as it does not impel the inadmissibility of the prosecution , only then leads to the exclusion of the evidence if the suspect concerned is harmed in an interest that the violated norm seeks to protect . This implies that in such a case an investigation of a violation of such a norm is not necessary , if the suspect himself has not been directly harmed by this < violation>.

CARDINAL . As to the compilation of the case - file , the court considers at the outset that the responsibility thereto rests primarily with the public prosecutor , who provides the case - file to the judge . In that file are to be included the data that in all reasonability may be of relevance to any decision to be taken by the judge , including possible exculpating evidence .

CARDINAL . It applies to all objections and requests by the defence , that these are to be substantiated by sufficiently concrete facts and/or circumstances and which are of relevance to the point made . Suppositions and suggestions are insufficient to this end .
CARDINAL . The court will now consider the requests of the accused .

CARDINAL . It is contended that no full disclosure has been made as to the investigation in the GPE . It is not excluded that more methods of investigation than taps has been used and that the GPE Prisma < criminal investigation > team was already itself actively involved in the investigation . The defence deduces this from the written remark on DATE by PERSON that the “ the United States’ Attorney ’s ORG of GPE and ORG currently are co - ordinating their law enforcement activities with the law enforcement agencies of the GPE ” and furthermore from the fact that PERSON police commissioner in charge of the ORG investigation team > states that on DATE more documents had been shown than < those > subsequently requested and disclosed .

CARDINAL . Mr E. has been extensively questioned twice about these matters by the investigating judge and the defence . It follows from his statements that the GPE police kept regular contacts with the NORP authorities about joint investigation targets - drug trafficking from LOC - and that in this framework it received a tip from the GPE about possibly punishable acts by Mr X. , which could have a follow - up in the GPE . Further consultations have occurred on a number of times . Subsequently , on DATE and in the presence of the public prosecutor , a conversation with , amongst others , PERSON has taken place in the GPE and , on DATE > by letter rogatory , the public prosecutor has requested the disclosure of the investigation results including the taps . Only the taps have been disclosed .

CARDINAL . From the statements of PERSON can not be deduced more than that there has been a consultation prior to CARDINAL DATE , but not that the GPE police has been actively involved in the GPE in investigation acts or that the GPE public prosecution department was conducting an investigation there . This can furthermore not be deduced from Ms D.’ remark on DATE . On DATE , the NORP authorities have informed the GPE colleagues of the investigation results obtained at that point in time .

CARDINAL . It is a fact that Mr E. declares that more documents have been shown and have been kept outside the case - file … and that he can not make public < statements about > some matters . When questioned , he indicates … that those other documents and matters are , inter alia , connected to another cocaine line . Since the order of the judge in GPE dated DATE on disclosure of documents only related to taps , the court considers at the outset that on DATE , in relation to the Tropical Wizzard case , for that reason only the taps have been disclosed and that < the > other documents shown concerned other cases , as indicated by Mr E.

CARDINAL . Given the previously formulated general framework , the court sees no terms in the defence ’s submissions to have a further investigation of the lawfulness and of the possible presence of other methods of investigation in the GPE . The submissions to this effect are insufficiently concretised and is for the greater part based on suppositions , whereas it has neither been substantiated that the methods used might be so unacceptable that the GPE public order comes into play .

CARDINAL . A lack of clarity nevertheless remains . On DATE > documents have been selected in the presence of the public prosecutor . The following day , he has requested the disclosure of more documents than solely the taps . It is possible that with this he means the selected material . Insofar as known to the court , only the taps have been disclosed and the public prosecutor has acquiesced in this < situation>. The question therefore arises as to what documents the public prosecutor has possibly had in mind - possibly those of CARDINAL DATE > - and whether these documents could be of relevance for any decision of the court . The defence points at this lack of clarity . The court finds reason in this to request the public prosecutor to submit a clarification in writing on this < point > and/or to remain available as a witness , albeit with the explicit limitation that in this < evidence > only concerns these questions . It must , however , be pointed out at this stage that this matter is likely , for the time being at least , to be of limited importance . The further case - file , which has led to the suspect ’s arrest , has in fact only been constituted following receipt of the taps .

CARDINAL . The court therefore rejects the requests by the defence in relation to the investigation in the GPE , i.e. the taking of evidence from PERSON , with the exception of the request in relation to the public prosecutor concerning the question as limited above .
CARDINAL . The defence suspects that Mr S. might have been involved in the investigation as an infiltrator . An investigation is requested . He would currently live in GPE .

CARDINAL . That Mr S. was an infiltrator is no more than a supposition . When questioned , PERSON stated that no infiltrator was involved in the GPE investigation and has submitted good grounds why Mr S. was not arrested then as a suspect ( he did not yet know Mr S. then and a suspicion of punishable acts had not yet arisen then ) .

CARDINAL . Remains the possibility that Mr S. was working for the investigation authorities in the GPE and infiltrated here < in the GPE Without further data , the court considers this possibility unlikely . The question is indeed to what purpose PERSON would have infiltrated here , let alone in the case of this suspect . Nothing appears from the documents that could indicate provocation by PERSON even denies that actually - or any other influence of PERSON on the actual importation of the cocaine .

CARDINAL . Mr S. was possibly here in the GPE as an observer , leaving aside the desirability of such activities on the territory of another ORG . As the GPE police themselves have observed , the court considers that such a role , assuming that he has played it , is of insufficient weight to investigate this , given the frameworks indicated above . All requests in relation to this matter are therefore rejected .

CARDINAL . It has been requested on behalf of the suspect to submit the full formal records of the observations . In the running formal records ( “ loop - p.v . ” ) summaries of the observations have been included . Whether in addition further formal records have been made is not known to the court . If so , then there is in principle reason to add those formal records to the case - file . The court will therefore request the Procurator General to do so or to indicate in writing why this can not take place ( in full ) .

CARDINAL . The suspect has further requested to hear the witness Mr M. about the suspect ’s role . The defence has not yet been able to question this witness . Nevertheless , the court rejects this request as insufficiently substantiated . It appears from the documents that Mr M. has hardly any knowledge of that role and it has not been indicated that he would know more .

CARDINAL The suspect has also requested to hear as a witness PERSON , living in GPE . She would be able to testify about a possible role of the suspect in the past . The court rejects this request . In the extensive NORP investigation numerous persons have been heard , amongst whom also a number in relation to the possible role of the suspect in DATE . It is unclear why a further statement needs to be added , whereas furthermore it has not been indicated that the witness requested has own knowledge about that part . That is only supposed . “
By letter of DATE , the public prosecutor PERSON submitted further explanations to ORG in relation to his letter rogatory addressed to the GPE authorities .

In the course of the hearing held on DATE before ORG , oral evidence was taken from the applicant , the public prosecutor PERSON and a further witness . The hearing of the public prosecutor PERSON was , however , restricted to the specific subject matter as explicitly defined by ORG . On DATE , ORG heard the parties’ final pleadings and fixed the date on which it would hand down its judgment .

In its judgment of DATE , ORG quashed the judgment of DATE , convicted the applicant of being involved in narcotics offences and of membership of a criminal organisation and sentenced him to CARDINAL years’ imprisonment .

It rejected the requests by the defence to adjourn the proceedings on appeal pending the inclusion of the records in relation to the observation of the garage at the final place of delivery of the cocaine or , alternatively , to take oral evidence from the police officers having observed that location ; to take , in the light of the testimony given by the public prosecutor PERSON , oral evidence from PERSON in relation to a possible informal co - operation between the NORP and NORP criminal investigation authorities already in DATE ; and to take further unrestricted oral evidence from the public prosecutor Mr V.

ORG held on the first point that , in conformity with the court ’s request , the public prosecutor had added CARDINAL formal records on the observation to the case - file . It considered itself sufficiently informed by these formal records and did not find a further investigation of this point necessary . Referring to its considerations stated on DATE and finding that the hearing held on DATE had not disclosed any further elements which should lead to a different finding , ORG also further rejected the second and third requests by the defence .

It based the applicant ’s conviction on the applicant ’s statement before ORG , statements taken from Mr X. before the police and the investigating judge , statements taken from other persons before the police and/or the investigating judge , formal records and the results of a forensic examination of substances seized by the police on DATE .

The applicant ’s subsequent appeal in cassation with ORG ( PERSON ) was rejected on DATE . Insofar as the applicant complained that ORG had unjustly rejected his requests to take further evidence , ORG accepted as correct the reasons stated by ORG for not acceding to those requests . As regards the decision to restrict the scope of further evidence sought from the public prosecutor PERSON , ORG held that ORG was at liberty to restrict the questioning of this witness to those points in respect of which the necessity to obtain further evidence had appeared . It further noted that it had not been argued and that it had not appeared that the defence had been restricted in the exercise of its rights in relation to the questioning of this witness about the subjects defined by ORG .
